feed.subtitle: Logging my daily progress with coding interview university

entry.title: Just take it a day at a time ðŸ™‚

link.title: Just take it a day at a time ðŸ™‚

entry.content:
I just saw the first video of the coding-interview-university, where a Harvard student explains basic asymptotic notation, like what does O(n), O(1), O(n^2) means and so on, which is kind of a breeze for anyone who has taken a few computer science classes. However, I do admit that I had forgotten what does Î©(n) means, and what does Î˜(n) means, and that made me be humble, because I realized that yes, there is a lot of knowledge I donâ€™t know.

I decided to also watch the second video in the asymptotic notation part of the study, and apart from the quick explanation about O(n log n), everything is pretty basic for someone who has had a algorithm analysis class in college, which I did. I hope I donâ€™t feel this throughout the entire journey, otherwise I shall have to pick something else to use as the path for my studies.

This may be a little unfair with the repository, which is filled with good information about computer science, interviews, resumes and everything to help someone find themselves a career in software engineering, and I do realize the author does indeed say that he has not studied computer science in college, so maybe I do need something else. Well, Iâ€™ll stick to the program at least for a week before jumping ship. Now, itâ€™s time to go back to do a few Hackerrank challenges

Thank you for reading!
entry.summary: I just saw the first video of the coding-interview-university, where a Harvard student explains basic asymptotic notation, like what does O(n), O(1), O(n^2) means and so on, which is kind of a breeze for anyone who has taken a few computer science classes. However, I do admit that I had forgotten what does Î©(n) means, and what does Î˜(n) means, and that made me be humble, because I realized that yes, there is a lot of knowledge I donâ€™t know.

entry.title: Better coder, better me
entry.content:
A few months after graduating, I have realized that I donâ€™t really know a lot of stuff that I should, and that there are thousands of improvementes that I can work on.

Because of that, Iâ€™ve decided that it is time to start re-learning a lot of basic computer science, while also starting to get deeper knowledge about cloud computing. For the CS part, Iâ€™ll be doing coding-interview-university alongside with hackerrank. For the cloud Stuff, I havenâ€™t decided my path yet. I currently work with AWS, using a lot of Lambda, Step Functions and API Gateway, however, I know that is only the tip of the iceberg.

The language I will be using for the most part will be Python, since I already use it a lot, however, sometimes I may challenge myself to work with C, just to check if I still am able to do low-level pointer stuff when messing with data-structures.

At the same time Iâ€™m doing this, I will write these blog posts in English, because I believe itâ€™s going to improve my ability to write and read in english. I also need to find a way to improve my speaking skills, but that is a problem for later

I wonâ€™t be posting everyday, but I will definitely try to post at least twice a week.

Thank you for reading!
